comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Nuns? Nurses? Women in uniform?  Hygiene or what.  It is strange to see the dress given the nature of the work they were doing!

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Very high ceiling without a picture rail where the flies used to breed. I cannot work out if they are gas mantles that have been converted to electric lights. I remember gas lights with 2 chains hanging to regulate the gas supply. www.1900s.org.uk/1900s-lighting.htm

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] I'm thinking volunteers, some of whom may well have been nurses. But given the nature of the enterprise and that it was probably run in a very disciplined manner, that they were expected to wear the apron and veil affair; and for hygiene too as you say...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: Probably standard Red Cross uniforms for the period.

comment.author: 37424391@N07
comment._content: The system they used to get in all our lives,.The schools & hospitals,.Now we can't get them out,.Thank you, Brenda,.did you happen to see this,. Smiling Eamon de Valera "Follier Upper"

comment.author: 37424391@N07
comment._content: They are nuns,.!! not nurses not red cross" The Church,.,!!!"  Thank you,.Respect,.!

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: One of those "nuns" is wearing a wedding ring.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] I think the lamp on the left may well be gas - there seems to be a mantle and the "shade" is very stained. As to the centrepiece, can't see any mechanism to regulate gas and brightness...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] Probably, though without the "red cross" itself

comment.author: 55597723@N02
comment._content: Nice Classic Photo. Times were not easy before Russian Revolution & WW1. However, I must apoligize for not knowing much about Irish History. I should study it online.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Beatrix Frances Petty-FitzMaurice (25 March 1877 – 5 August 1953) "On 16 October 1897, she married Henry Beresford, 6th Marquess of Waterford (and would be styled as Marchioness of Waterford); the couple had six children. The Marquess died in 1911, and on 19 August 1918, she remarried, to Osborne Beauclerk, 12th Duke of St Albans." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beatrix_Beauclerk,_Duchess_of_St_Al... She would be aged 38 at the time of this photo.

comment.author: 16489083@N05
comment._content: Luv this... great need they were meeting!!!
comment.authorname: maorlando God kept us 2012 leaning on Him 2013

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/55597723@N02] No need to apologise, John! Hopefully, you're picking up a lot about Irish history here without even trying...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Thanks for info on the Marchioness. I wasn't necessarily saying it was her in the photo - the only one in Mufti - but I've had a look at some photos of the Marchioness that we have in our collections, and it certainly could be her. I will upload one this week, and you eagle eyes can see what you think...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
